content.description:
This route is only a couple moves long but its fun and requires some flexibility. Start with both feet on a low ledge with a nice area to move feet around. Left hand goes to a crimp high and to the left. Right hand holds a low edge. Left foot goes high to press toe into a 1 inch wide/6 inch long edge that runs at 45 degree angle. Right hand goes up high for a sloper on the top (not really any obvious good holds here). Left hand turns into press/pushup position and pressing on this and the right foothold move up until you can bring your left foot over the roof. From here its pretty easy to walk the rest of the way to the top.

 Crux is the high right foot placement. I'm not very flexible and had to warm-up the hips to reach it. Once that foot is placed its not too hard but the next press to get over the roof requires some commitment.
content.protection: There's water and sloped/slippery rock at the base of this climb. Overall its not a great landing. The rock is big enough to hold a pad but about half of the pad won't have a solid base. Stepping onto the first ledge isn't too risky and I kinda felt my way around for a while before I committed to the big step up move.
content.location: Located in the middle of the cascade of rocks that leads to the shore area. If you walk toward the shore on the rocks in the middle of the water it will be on your left side.

content.description: Start low, one the first ledge.

This slightly overhanging boulder problem starts by squeezing the boulder from both sides. This problem has cool heel hook and mantel. Roughly three moves depending on height. However, the boulder that Squeezy sits on hovers over the water, and can be slightly risky at best.

Slab climb with careful feet.

 Start with one hand on the arete, and one in the small pocket. Climb up to the fourth 'step'. Top out and walk down the steps backward.

 Beware, there is a small tree that you have to go through, and the fall will come down onto a slope. Make sure you don't slip on the moss.
content.location: The arete to the left (if you're facing the cliff) of Project 2. It's mossy.

content.description: Easy mantle to good holds. May need to fight a fisher for the spot!
content.location: On the river side of the trail down river from the Gulf Branch stream.

content.description: Start on low-cut feet and the handholds in the photo. Work hands and feet left to the sidepull pinch and good left ledge (off original rock). Then dyno to the high ledge and top out the climb. Important: All granite holds are off and so is the pocket foothold at the start.
content.location: A tall vertical boulder wall on the left of the Potomac Heritage trail about half a mile downstream of the end of the gulf branch trail. It is right next to the water and there is a nice tree to lie on hanging out into the water.

content.description: Start with low feet on the small left cut, right edge, and hands on crimps in the photo. move up and right to the edge and then work your way left with good feet to the top out on the higher ledge.
content.location: A tall vertical boulder wall on the left of the Potomac Heritage trail about half a mile downstream of the end of the gulf branch trail. It is right next to the water and there is a nice tree to lie on hanging out into the water.

content.description: Start on tiny crimp in middle (4 feet up) and larger jug to the right of the climb. The crux is raising your leg to the same jug
content.location: In between Hound Dog and Crystal King of Gulf Branch.

content.description: Fun pull on the jugs to the right of the dihedral. It's more fun if you use footholds on the face! Watch out for a wobbly bit on the left side of the first jug.
content.location: Just to the right of the dihedral

content.description: Start of the chalked up hold in the dihedral, move out left to the face holds then go straight up. It's much easier if you're tall.
Climb this really cool looking dihedral.
content.location: Head downstream 200ft.  Boulder problem is part of the cliff line.

content.description: Sit start low and to the right and then crimp and heel hook your way up left!
content.protection: One or two pads, probably a spotter so you don't tumble down to the trail.
content.location: Other side of the trail from Moontle

content.description: Start with both hands on the right edge underneath the small lip. Use the obvious left foot and a right foot around the corner. Then work your hands up the prow and top out on the far left side.
content.protection: one or two crash pads and maybe a spotter
content.location: Around the back of Dark Blok facing the river.

content.description: Go right of Direct. The crux is not dragging your butt on the ground.
Climb straight up from the starting sloper. Using a left heel hook waaaay out left is useful for this lowball.
content.location: Dark block on the river side of the trail downstream from the Gulf Branch stream.

content.description: As someone who has climbed every established climb in Gulf Branch, and countless hidden gems, this is by far my far my favorite out here.Start at bottom ledge by the pictured crash pad, with one foot near the bottom, and one foot lower on the same ledge as your hands. First move is to a crimp roughly 3 feet above. Top out DIRECTLY OVER the climb.Notes: V shaped gap is off-limits, as that finish would constitute a much easier climb.Top out must be over the climb, do not climb around edge
content.location: First stretch of rock on the right side of the river, slightly to the left of Bigfoot and Hound-dogDirectly next to giant fallen tree trunk.

content.description:
Start in the cave, climb right on a horizontal crack. Once the crack ends at the triangle, follow a series of ledges up to the top.

 To be clear: This is a highball boulder onto sharp rocks. Please avoid without appropriate highball crashpads.
content.location: Walk downstream the river for about 5 minutes.

content.description: The Boulder sits in the middle of the shore, out in the open, Start in the lower lefthand pocket and as you move up, continue right. The boulder has cool vertical pocket holds, and is roughly four moves.

Crimpy holds roughly four feet up, smear feet to start. As you move up the arete on top until you encounter better feet and good handholds until you reach the top of the arete. Top out to the left. Be careful, as a fall could hurt a little. You'll be fine as long as you have crashpads (no promises).
content.location: To the right of Hound Dog, to the left of Kermit. Third climb near the waterfall. Diagonal with a large point at the top, above the slide.

content.description:
Located along the Potomac Heritage Trail, this area has a few boulders and potential top rope climbs. The National Park Service owns the Potomac Heritage Trail and shoreline. 

  Routes are ordered from Left (upstream) and Right (downstream)
